Package tage.input

Class InputManager

java.lang.Object
tage.input.InputManager
All Implemented Interfaces:
IInputManager
public class InputManager extends Object implements IInputManager
This class implements the IInputManager interface and acts as the central management point for all input devices available for controlling a game. This includes the keyboard, the mouse, and any "game controllers" installed on the machine -- gamepads, joysticks, steering wheels, dance mats, and so forth. Instantiating an InputManager causes it to query the underlying system to determine what devices are available and then to begin managing them on behalf of the invoking application.

Applications can register ("associate") IAction objects with individual controller components (e.g. buttons, keys, or axes) by invoking associateAction(Component.Identifier, IAction, INPUT_ACTION_TYPE) in the InputManager; registered IActions will be invoked (via a callback to their IAction.performAction(float, Event) method and based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE) whenever input events occur on the corresponding input component.

Note: it is the responsibility of an application (game) to periodically invoke the InputManager's update(float) method to insure that input events are properly forwarded. Typically, update(float) should be invoked on each iteration of the application's "gameloop".

This implementation of the InputManager class uses the "JInput" (net.java.games.input) package for underlying device access. JInput contains support for device access via the Java AWT, Microsoft's DirectInput, Linux, Mac OS-X, WinTablet, and direct raw device input. JInput automatically queries the underlying OS and attempts to use the appropriate device-access plugin.

Author:
John Clevenger; based on a development version by Russell Bolles

  • Constructor Details

    • InputManager

      public InputManager()
      Constructs a new InputManager using JInput for the underlying device handling and with "verbosity level" zero. Invoking this constructor is the same as invoking new InputManager(0)

    • InputManager

      public InputManager(int verbosity)
      Constructs a new InputManager using JInput for the underlying device handling and using the specified "verbosity level". Verbosity level 0 is silent; values greater than zero specify increasing levels of informational output:
      verbosity=1 causes the constructor to output the JInput version number;
      verbosity=2 causes the constructor to also list the discovered controllers;
      verbosity=3 causes the constructor to also list the components associated with each controller;
      verbosity=4 causes the InputManager to display every event received from components.

  • Method Details

    • update

      public void update(float time)
      update(float time) causes the InputManager to update its information on the state of all input devices and then invoke, in the manner specified by the IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE of each component, any IActions associated with components. This method should be called by the application (game) code, typically once per iteration of the "game loop".
      Specified by:
      update in interface IInputManager
      Parameters:
      time - - the elapsed time since the last time this method was called, normally given in milliseconds; this time is passed to the IAction.performAction(float, Event) method for any IAction objects invoked as a result of this call to update()

    • associateAction

      @Deprecated public IAction associateAction(net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component, IAction action, IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
      Deprecated.
      Description copied from interface: IInputManager
      associateAction() causes the InputManager to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component (for example, key 'A', etc). Associating an IAction with a component causes update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction by calling its IAction.performAction(float,net.java.games.input.Event) method based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE.

      NOTE: this method is deprecated and is provided for backward compatibility with older versions of Sage; use IInputManager.associateAction(String, Component.Identifier, IAction, INPUT_ACTION_TYPE) instead. If this method is called it defaults to associating the specified IAction with the keyboard returned by IInputManager.getKeyboardName(); if the specified component is not an instance of Component.Identifier.Key a warning is printed and the request is ignored.

      Specified by:
      associateAction in interface IInputManager
      Parameters:
      component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
      action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
      actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
      Returns:
      the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

    • associateAction

      public IAction associateAction(String controllerName, net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component, IAction action, IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
      Description copied from interface: IInputManager
      associateAction() causes the IInputManager object to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component of a specific controller. Associating an IAction with a controller and component causes IInputManager.update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction, by calling its IAction.performAction(float,Event) method, based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE (for example, each time the specified component on the specified controller changes state).
      Specified by:
      associateAction in interface IInputManager
      Parameters:
      controllerName - - the name of the controller, as returned by Controller.getName() with which the action is to be associated
      component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
      action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
      actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
      Returns:
      the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

    • associateAction

      public IAction associateAction(net.java.games.input.Controller controller, net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component, IAction action, IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
      associateAction() causes the IInputManager object to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component of a specific controller. Associating an IAction with a controller and component causes IInputManager.update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction, by calling its IAction.performAction(float,Event) method, based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE (for example, each time the specified component on the specified controller changes state).
      Specified by:
      associateAction in interface IInputManager
      Parameters:
      controller - - the controller with which the action is to be associated
      component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
      action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
      actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
      Returns:
      the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

    • getKeyboardController

      public net.java.games.input.Controller getKeyboardController(int n)

      Specified by:
      getKeyboardController in interface IInputManager
      Parameters:
      n - Occurrence number, such as 1 for first occurrence of a keyboard, or 2 for second occurrence of a keyboard.

    • getKeyboardControllerWithNComponents

      Specified by:

      Parameters:
